intro: Myginda puberula, commonly known as the hairy myginda, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its pubescent (hairy) stems and leaves, which provide a distinctive texture. Its flowers are typically pink or purple, with five petals and a prominent central stamen. Myginda puberula is often found in moist, shaded environments such as forest understories.
